elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The ultrasonic reaction of Ag2O, 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) and Na2B4O5(OH)4⋅8H2O (borax) under ammoniacal medium gave rise to an unexpected 3D Ag(I) supramolecular sandwich lamellar framework, {[Ag2(bpp)2(H2O)2]⋅[(H3BO3)3(CO3)⋅2H2O]} n  (1), which consists of 2D silver-bpp cationic host and water-borate-carbonate anionic guest layers. The present 2D anionic layer is formed by fused H2O-H3BO3-CO3 2- anionic rosette ribbons, in which H3BO3 is obtained via in situ hydrolysis of borax and CO3 2- derived from absorption of CO2 in air. Interestingly, an unprecedented [CO3 2-⋅3(H3BO3)] hydrogen-bonding aggregate having the shape of one concave three-leaved propeller is found in the anionic rosette ribbon.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The title compound features a 3D supramolecular sandwich architecture that consists of 2D silver-bpp cationic layers and water-borate-carbonate anionic layers. The anionic layer is formed by fused H2O-H3BO3-CO3 2- anionic rosette ribbons. The first hydrogen-bonding aggregate [CO3 2-⋅3(H3BO3)] shaped-like one concave three-leaved propeller is found in the anionic layer.

elements.clean_text:
Highlights

► The Ag(I) compound containing the H2O-H3BO3-CO3 2- anionic rosette ribbons was synthesized. ► The first [CO3 2-⋅3(H3BO3)] hydrogen-bonding aggregate is found in the compound.

Over the years, supramolecular chemistry has developed to allow the rational design and preparation of supramolecular architectures through non-covalent interactions, in which it is crucial to meet both geometric and energetic prerequisites . Dominant among such molecular interactions is hydrogen bonding, which is frequently the overriding factor in the design of supramolecular assemblages owing to its relatively strong bonding strength, directionality and flexibility. Thus, a great variety of zero-, one- and two-dimensional supramolecular structures such as cages, chains, sheets, ribbons, tapes and rosettes assembled by multiple hydrogen bonds or hydrogen bond networks, have been designed and synthesized to induce a desirable crystal packing . Among the supramolecular structures, chemical entities bearing rosette motifs have attracted considerable interest in connection with supramolecular self-assembly of potentially useful organic functional materials . One of effective strategies constructing the hydrogen-bonded rosette ribbons or layers is to make use of C  3 -symmetric molecular building blocks of different shapes and sizes such that their donor and acceptor sites are perfectly. CO3 2- as a simple oxo-anion can easily act as six acceptor hydrogen bonds and accordingly is a good candidate as the core of C  3 -symmetric molecular building blocks. Thus, several interesting supramolecular hydrogen-bonded architectures involving CO3 2- have been isolated and characterized by Mak and co-workers . On the other hand, boric acid, B(OH)3, would be expected to be a good building block for supramolecular hydrogen-bonded structures by virtue of the presence of three -OH groups oriented in a planar triangular fashion. Combination of B(OH)3 as proton donors and CO3 2- as proton acceptors for the construction of C  3 -symmetric molecular building blocks is, however rare. In the present communication, we reports a new kind of "fused-rosette ribbon" built of the hetertrimer [CO3 2-⋅3(H3BO3)] aggregate and water in the ratio of 1:2, which was found in the compound, {[Ag2(bpp)2(H2O)2]⋅[(H3BO3)3(CO3)⋅2H2O]} n  (1).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was obtained using ‘one-pot’ methodology by ultrasonic treatment of a mixture of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) and Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>B<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (borax) in methanol–H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL, <ce:italic>v</ce:italic>:<ce:italic>v</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1:1) binary solvent with initial pH of 10 in air , of which molecular structure was determined with single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The compositions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were further deduced from elemental analyses and IR spectrum. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) has been used to check phase purity of the bulky sample in the solid state . For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the experimental powder pattern is in good agreement with the simulated pattern generated from the result of single crystal diffraction data. The solid FT–IR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a very intense broad band around 3425<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> attributed to the presence of water molecules . X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis  reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/n with an asymmetric unit comprising two Ag(I) ions, two coordinated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules, two bpp ligands, one CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anion, and three H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> molecules as well as two lattice water molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Both Ag1 and Ag2 are similarily located in T-shaped (two N<ce:inf loc="post">bpp</ce:inf> and one O<ce:inf loc="post">water</ce:inf>) coordination geometries, respectively. The Ag–N and Ag–O bond lengths fall in the ranges of 2.122(3)–2.131(3) and 2.571(3)–2.700(3) Å, respectively. All of bond lengths are well-matched to those observed in similar compounds . The largest angles around Ag1 and Ag2 are 168.68(13) and 172.74(13)°, respectively. The bpp ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> adopt <ce:italic>TT</ce:italic> conformations (where <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> = <ce:italic>Trans</ce:italic>) with N···N separations of 9.247(6)–9.302(6) Å and link Ag(I) ions to form 1D sinusoidal cationic chains with Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> repeating units (period 24.778(3) Å) on which the coordinated water molecules dangle. Based on the view of supramolecular interactions, adjoining 1D cationic chains are further arrayed in inversion parallel fashion through effective Ag∙∙∙π interactions between the closest aromatic rings of bpp ligands and silver ions, in which the shortest distance from aromatic carbon to Ag(I) ion (3.330(6) and 3.339(6) Å) is at the upper limit of 2.89–3.37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å range of Ag-η<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> arene π interactions , to generate a 2D cationic sheet {[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
, resulting in the coordinated aqua molecules staggered parse in two sides of the sheet, which are participated in the fabrication of guest hydrogen-bonding layer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 was obtained using ‘one-pot' methodology by ultrasonic treatment of a mixture of Ag2O, 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) and Na2B4O5(OH)4⋅8H2O (borax) in methanol-H2O (10mL, v:v =1:1) binary solvent with initial pH of 10 in air , of which molecular structure was determined with single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The compositions of 1 were further deduced from elemental analyses and IR spectrum. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) has been used to check phase purity of the bulky sample in the solid state . For 1, the experimental powder pattern is in good agreement with the simulated pattern generated from the result of single crystal diffraction data. The solid FT-IR spectrum of 1 shows a very intense broad band around 3425cm-1 attributed to the presence of water molecules . X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis  reveals that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with an asymmetric unit comprising two Ag(I) ions, two coordinated H2O molecules, two bpp ligands, one CO3 2- anion, and three H3BO3 molecules as well as two lattice water molecules ( ). Both Ag1 and Ag2 are similarily located in T-shaped (two Nbpp and one Owater) coordination geometries, respectively. The Ag-N and Ag-O bond lengths fall in the ranges of 2.122(3)-2.131(3) and 2.571(3)-2.700(3) Å, respectively. All of bond lengths are well-matched to those observed in similar compounds . The largest angles around Ag1 and Ag2 are 168.68(13) and 172.74(13)°, respectively. The bpp ligands in 1 adopt TT conformations (where T = Trans) with N⋅⋅⋅N separations of 9.247(6)-9.302(6) Å and link Ag(I) ions to form 1D sinusoidal cationic chains with Ag2(bpp)2 repeating units (period 24.778(3) Å) on which the coordinated water molecules dangle. Based on the view of supramolecular interactions, adjoining 1D cationic chains are further arrayed in inversion parallel fashion through effective Ag∙∙∙π interactions between the closest aromatic rings of bpp ligands and silver ions, in which the shortest distance from aromatic carbon to Ag(I) ion (3.330(6) and 3.339(6) Å) is at the upper limit of 2.89-3.37Å range of Ag-η6 arene π interactions , to generate a 2D cationic sheet {[Ag2(bpp)2(H2O)2]2+}n , resulting in the coordinated aqua molecules staggered parse in two sides of the sheet, which are participated in the fabrication of guest hydrogen-bonding layer.

The measured bond distances of B-OH between 1.339(6) and 1.368(5) Å are in good agreement with those in M⋅2B(OH)3 (where M = Melamine)  and (NEt4)2[BO(OH)2]2⋅B(OH)3⋅5H2O . In this context, it is worthy of note that C-O distances of CO3 2- from 1.272(5) to 1.290(4) Å are much shorter than B-O bonds which assists us to distinguish CO3 2-. As shown in  , each carbonate ion C1 (henceforth conveniently referred to by their central carbon or boron atoms labels in bold type) providing four acceptor sites are connected with two independent boric acid molecules B2 and B3 both functioning as donors through charge-assisted Oborate-H⋅⋅⋅O- carbonate hydrogen bonds, forming a V-shaped hetertrimer motif [B2⋅⋅⋅C1⋅⋅⋅B3]. The hetertrimer contains two similar rings labeled by A and A' which both have the same motif described by the graph-set notation N 2 =R2 2(8) . As the matter of fact, the R2 2(8) graph of hydrogen bonds is one of the 24 most frequently observed bimolecular cyclic hydrogen-bonded synthons in crystal engineering . Another V-shaped [(H2O)2⋅⋅⋅B1⋅⋅⋅(H2O)2] unit crosslinks two adjacent hetertrimers [B2⋅⋅⋅C1⋅⋅⋅B3] by forming two pairs of O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds which display two types of ring motifs: B and B', N 4  = R4 4(12), giving rise to an infinite crinkled strip. Neighboring strips are articulated by a pair of Oborate-H⋅⋅⋅O- carbonate hydrogen bonds like a hinge [A", N 2  = R2 2(8)] in which each B1 provides two exo-orientated donor sites and C1 unit provides two remaining acceptor sites, leading to a fused-rossette ribbon. A closer look at the resulting fused-rossette ribbon reveals that two hetertrimer motifs [B2⋅⋅⋅C1⋅⋅⋅B3] can be expanded or disrupted by the inclusion of water molecules to form a "pseudo-rosetter" [C, N 8 =R8 6(12)] with inner and outer diameters of ca. 4.41 and 10.78Å. As shown in , adjacent fused-rosette ribbons are further organized into a well-ordered 2D anionic guest layer by four different hydrogen-bonded motifs including two six-membered cyclic rings [D, N 2 =R2 2(8); F, N 4 =R4 4(10)], one five-membered [E, N 5 =R5 4(10)] and one four-membered cyclic ring [G, N 4 =R4 4(8)]. Notably, the hexagon pattern D [N 2 =R2 2(8)] is made up of the exo/endo of the H-B(OH)2 hydrogen-bonded dimer, which is similar to those formed by carboxylic acids or carboxamides .

<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The most prominent feature of the anionic guest layer in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the formation of the [CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>

Generally, the carbonate ions are known to form six  to ten  acceptor hydrogen bonds in their crystalline compounds. In the present work, the trigonal planar carbonate ion forms six acceptor hydrogen bonds with the convergent O–H donor sites from three independent H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> molecules. As demonstrated by a CSD (Cambridge Structure Database) survey with the help of ConQuest Version 1.3 , there are only 3 structures containing molecular aggregates of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>

elements.clean_text: The most prominent feature of the anionic guest layer in 1 is the formation of the [CO3 2-⋅3(H3BO3)] aggregate, which may be described as one concave three-leaved propeller. Generally, the carbonate ions are known to form six  to ten  acceptor hydrogen bonds in their crystalline compounds. In the present work, the trigonal planar carbonate ion forms six acceptor hydrogen bonds with the convergent O-H donor sites from three independent H3BO3 molecules. As demonstrated by a CSD (Cambridge Structure Database) survey with the help of ConQuest Version 1.3 , there are only 3 structures containing molecular aggregates of H3BO3 and CO3 2-, of which 2 form hydrogen-bonding patterns shaped like concave three-leaved propeller structures in which single carbonate ion is surrounded by four OH donor groups from two H3BO3 and two NH donor groups from one urea or guanidinium formulating {CO3 2-⋅2(H3BO3)⋅[(NH2)2CO]}  and {CO3 2-⋅2(H3BO3)⋅[C(NH2)3 +]}  aggregate (where urea=(NH2)2CO and guanidinium=C(NH2)3 +) ( ). Therefore, the [CO3 2-⋅3(H3BO3)] aggregate is the first example of one CO3 2- anion hydrogen-bonded three H3BO3 molecules, which is structurally comparable to {CO3 2-⋅3[C(NH2)3 +]} aggregate .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Furthermore, the well-ordered 2D cationic and anionic layer in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are found to be stacked along ~[010] direction following the alternating –ABAB– sequence, where A and B represents {[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> cationic layer and {[(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> anionic layer, respectively, resulting in a 3D metallo-supramolecular sandwich lamerllar network, in which water–borate–carbonate anionic layered species are occupied in the interlayer spacing between metallo-organic networks .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, the well-ordered 2D cationic and anionic layer in 1 are found to be stacked along ~[010] direction following the alternating -ABAB- sequence, where A and B represents {[Ag2(bpp)2(H2O)2]2+}n cationic layer and {[(H3BO3)3(CO3)⋅2H2O]2-}n anionic layer, respectively, resulting in a 3D metallo-supramolecular sandwich lamerllar network, in which water-borate-carbonate anionic layered species are occupied in the interlayer spacing between metallo-organic networks .

<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">There is one remaining issue that needs to be resolved: where and how H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> molecules and CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>

The formation of boric acid molecules are unambiguously related to the hydrolysis of borax in alkaline conditions (25% NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> aqueous solution used) . Attempts to run the reactions in the absence of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> could not lead to the isolation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. On the other hand, the yield of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> could be improved from 22.8% to 58.2% by running the experiment in a CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> rich atmosphere. All the experimental results clearly suggest that the CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions derive from the absorption and hydration of atmospheric carbon dioxide. The hydration of aerial CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> gives H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, which in turn undergoes deprotonation in alkaline conditions. The existence of the CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was further confirmed by FT-IR spectrum measured in the solid state. Strong carbonate-related vibrations are observed at 1422<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>
. It should be noteworthy that NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O proved to be vital for the formation of the title compound, although it was not incorporated in the final products. As a base, NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O firstly favours the transformation of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> to CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ions <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> hydration . On the other hand, it may also react with Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> to form unstable species [Ag(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](OH) , which facilitates the growth of single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. elements.clean_text: There is one remaining issue that needs to be resolved: where and how H3BO3 molecules and CO3 2- anions come from when considering the starting reagents only containing Ag2O, bpp and Na2B4O5(OH)4⋅8H2O. The formation of boric acid molecules are unambiguously related to the hydrolysis of borax in alkaline conditions (25% NH3 aqueous solution used) . Attempts to run the reactions in the absence of CO2 could not lead to the isolation of 1. On the other hand, the yield of 1 could be improved from 22.8% to 58.2% by running the experiment in a CO2 rich atmosphere. All the experimental results clearly suggest that the CO3 2- anions derive from the absorption and hydration of atmospheric carbon dioxide. The hydration of aerial CO2 gives H2CO3, which in turn undergoes deprotonation in alkaline conditions. The existence of the CO3 2- anions in 1 was further confirmed by FT-IR spectrum measured in the solid state. Strong carbonate-related vibrations are observed at 1422cm-1 . It should be noteworthy that NH3⋅H2O proved to be vital for the formation of the title compound, although it was not incorporated in the final products. As a base, NH3⋅H2O firstly favours the transformation of CO2 to CO3 2- ions via hydration . On the other hand, it may also react with AgI to form unstable species [Ag(NH3)2](OH) , which facilitates the growth of single crystals of 1. In sum, the main reaction process for the formaion of 1 in aqueous solution could be summarized as follows:  (1)   C  O 2  +  H 2  O ⇌  H 2  C  O 3  ⇌  H +  + H C  O 3    -  ⇌ 2  H +  + C  O 3     2 -         (2)       B 4   O 5     O H   4     2 -   + 7  H 2  O ⇌ 4  H 3  B  O 3  + 2 O  H -        (3)     A  g +  + b p p +  H 3  B  O 3  + C  O 3     2 -   +  H 2  O    →  N  H 3  ⋅  H 2  O             A  g 2     b p p   2      H 2  O   2    ⋅       H 3  B  O 3    3    C  O 3    ⋅ 2  H 2  O

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Excitation of solid powder sample <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at 330<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm produces an emission with a maximum at <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 460<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm . When compared to the photoluminescence spectrum of the free bpp ligand (λ<ce:inf loc="post">em</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>445<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), the emission bands of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is red-shifted by 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, which could be assigned to π*<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>π electronic transition of bpp ligand . The red shift of the emission compared with that of free bpp ligand may be attributed to the ligation of the bpp ligands to Ag(I) centers by enhancing its conformational rigidity and decreasing the non-radiative energy loss .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Excitation of solid powder sample 1 at 330nm produces an emission with a maximum at ca. 460nm . When compared to the photoluminescence spectrum of the free bpp ligand (λem =445nm), the emission bands of 1 is red-shifted by 15nm, which could be assigned to π*→π electronic transition of bpp ligand . The red shift of the emission compared with that of free bpp ligand may be attributed to the ligation of the bpp ligands to Ag(I) centers by enhancing its conformational rigidity and decreasing the non-radiative energy loss .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">In conclusion, the present study demonstrates a new kind of “fused-rosette ribbon” built of the first hetertrimer [CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>·3(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)] aggregate shaped like one concave three-leaved propeller and water in the ratio of 1:2 was sandwiched by a Ag(I) host {[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·[(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), in which H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> is obtained <ce:italic>via in situ</ce:italic> hydrolysis of borax and CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> derived from absorption of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in air. In addition, attempts to obtain SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> as proton acceptors in place of CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ions by running the experiment in a SO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> rich atmosphere are currently under way in our laboratory.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, the present study demonstrates a new kind of "fused-rosette ribbon" built of the first hetertrimer [CO3 2-⋅3(H3BO3)] aggregate shaped like one concave three-leaved propeller and water in the ratio of 1:2 was sandwiched by a Ag(I) host {[Ag2(bpp)2(H2O)2]⋅[(H3BO3)3(CO3)⋅2H2O]} n  (1), in which H3BO3 is obtained via in situ hydrolysis of borax and CO3 2- derived from absorption of CO2 in air. In addition, attempts to obtain SO3 2- as proton acceptors in place of CO3 2- ions by running the experiment in a SO2 rich atmosphere are currently under way in our laboratory.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0050" view="all">Synthesis of {[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·[(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>): A mixture of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (116 mg, 0.5 mmol), bpp (205 mg, 1 mmol) and Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>B<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (382 mg, 1 mmol) was stirred in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH–H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O binary solvent (10 mL, v/v, 1:1) under ultrasonic treatment (160 W, 40 kHz, 40°C) in air for 15 min. Then, an aqueous NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> solution (25%) was dropped into the mixture to give a clear solution. The resultant filtrate was allowed to evaporate slowly in darkness at ambient temperature. After one week, colorless plate crystals were obtained in 22.8% yield (based on Ag). They were washed with small volumes of cold CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH and diethyl ether. Anal. Calcd (%) for C<ce:inf loc="post">27</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">44</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>B<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>: C, 34.91; H, 4.77; N, 6.03. Found: C, 35.40; H, 4.85; N, 6.11. Selected IR peaks (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>): 3425(s), 3069(w), 2932(w), 2863(w), 1609(s), 1422(s), 1346(m), 1220(m), 1070 (m), 1007(m), 807 (m), 706 (w), 612(m), 512(m).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of {[Ag2(bpp)2(H2O)2]⋅[(H3BO3)3(CO3)⋅2H2O}n(1): A mixture of Ag2O (116 mg, 0.5 mmol), bpp (205 mg, 1 mmol) and Na2B4O5(OH)4⋅8H2O (382 mg, 1 mmol) was stirred in CH3OH-H2O binary solvent (10 mL, v/v, 1:1) under ultrasonic treatment (160 W, 40 kHz, 40°C) in air for 15 min. Then, an aqueous NH3 solution (25%) was dropped into the mixture to give a clear solution. The resultant filtrate was allowed to evaporate slowly in darkness at ambient temperature. After one week, colorless plate crystals were obtained in 22.8% yield (based on Ag). They were washed with small volumes of cold CH3OH and diethyl ether. Anal. Calcd (%) for C27H44Ag2B3N4O16: C, 34.91; H, 4.77; N, 6.03. Found: C, 35.40; H, 4.85; N, 6.11. Selected IR peaks (cm-1): 3425(s), 3069(w), 2932(w), 2863(w), 1609(s), 1422(s), 1346(m), 1220(m), 1070 (m), 1007(m), 807 (m), 706 (w), 612(m), 512(m).

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0055" view="all">See the supporting information.</ce:simple-para><ce:simple-para id="sp0060" view="all">Crystal data for 1: C27H44Ag2B3N4O16 (Mr = 928.83), monoclinic, space group P21/n (No. 14); a = 12.813(2) Å, b = 17.781(3) Å, c = 17.338(3) Å, β = 109.619(3)° V = 3720.9(11) Å3, Z = 4, Dc = 1.658<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3</ce:sup>, μ(Mo–Kα) = 1.126 mm−1, R1/wR2 = 0.0485/0.1101 [I > 2σ(I)] and 0.0590/0.1156 (for all data), GOF = 1.087, max./min. residual electron density, 0.840/−0.543<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>e<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3. Crystal structure analysis: Diffraction data of 1 were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID Image Plate single crystal diffractometer with a using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) operating at 50 kV and 90 mA in ω scan mode at 173K. Absorption correction was applied by correction of symmetry-equivalent reflections using the ABSCOR program . Structural solution and full-matrix least-squares refinement based on F2 were performed with the SHELXS-97  and SHELXL-97  program package, respectively. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were generated geometrically and refined with isotropic temperature factors. The hydrogen atoms of oxygen atoms were located in the difference Fourier maps and refined with fixed mode.</ce:simple-para>

cln_elements.clean_text:
Excitation of solid powder sample 1 at 330nm produces an emission with a maximum at ca. 460nm . When compared to the photoluminescence spectrum of the free bpp ligand (λem =445nm), the emission bands of 1 is red-shifted by 15nm, which could be assigned to π*→π electronic transition of bpp ligand . The red shift of the emission compared with that of free bpp ligand may be attributed to the ligation of the bpp ligands to Ag(I) centers by enhancing its conformational rigidity and decreasing the non-radiative energy loss .

See the supporting information.
